metadata.title: COVID-19 incidence and mortality in the Metropolitan Region, Chile: time, space, 1 and structural factors

abstract.text: Chile has been heavily affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. This article analyzes the 17 association of different groups of factors-demographic, health-related, and 18 socioeconomic-on COVID-19-related outcomes. Using the municipalities of the 19 Metropolitan Region the study looks at the role of time dynamics, space and place in 20 cases and deaths during a 100-days period. 21 Results show that common and idiosyncratic elements that explain the prevalence and 22 dynamics of infections and mortality, with an important role of social determinants of 23 health, particularly multidimensional poverty index and use of public transportation, in 24 explaining differences in outcomes.

body_text.text: but also can be relevant to understand patterns in deaths, e.g. if sudden outbreaks collapse 105 the healthcare system. variables are expected to explain mainly COVID-19-related health outcomes (deaths), as 151 they are proxies for healthcare access and quality and also reflect other broader 152 inequalities in the population. A dummy variable was constructed to capture whether 153 individuals report having at least one COVID-19-related health conditions, as reported by 154 the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the information reported by 155 the Chilean Ministry of Health, (13, 57, 58). 156 Finally, several variables that capture the socioeconomic level were considered. First, 157 water availability can be seen both as a socioeconomic and health indicator. Given the 158 nature of the virus, access to water is expected to impact people's preventive behavior, 159 particularly when hand washing has been identified as a key prevention strategy for the redefine poverty to include anything and everything that contributes to poor health, we 174 will make little progress either in theory or practice." All these variables can explain infections and deaths by 178 capturing the household's structural inability to follow the preventive measures (hand-179 washing, use of face masks, physical distancing, and quarantines) and seek healthcare 180 (e.g. health literacy) (70-75). Finally, the use of public transportation and the availability 181 of green spaces capture people's ability to stay at home and comply with social 182 distancing strategies. These are expected to impact the infection rate but can also 183 influence COVID-19 deaths, since they also show difficulty to move within the city, a 184 factor that could be relevant in case of health emergencies (76,77) 185 Finally, maps and spatial information were obtained from the website of the Inter- 186 Ministerial Committee on Geographic Information (78). To acknowledge the temporal dynamics of the disease, the study uses a standardized 100-201 days period since the first case was reported in each municipality. As for the role of space 202 and place in explaining COVID-19 cases and deaths, we used a spatial analysis approach 203 to look at the data.

To identify the determinants of infection and mortality due to COVID-19 in the 205 Metropolitan Region in Chile, we carried out multivariable regressions to explain the set 206 of dependent variables, using the three groups of explanatory variables described above. The first step in the spatial analysis is the definition of neighbors. In this case, we used a 215 first-order queen contiguity matrix, i.e. we defined as neighbors all municipalities that 216 share a border. Given the nature of the data-the existence of clusters in different areas of 217 the region and the high heterogeneity in the size of the municipalities-a distance-based 218 approach was discarded (79) .

To understand the impact of different variables in the incidence and mortality due to CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license It is made available under a is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. (which was not certified by peer review) preprint

The copyright holder for this this version posted September 18, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.09.15.20194951 doi: medRxiv preprint regression's residuals. This test shows whether the residuals are randomly distributed. If 226 the null hypothesis is rejected, the OLS analysis needs to be adjusted to consider the 227 spatial effects. There are two main strategies to estimate spatial autoregressive models: 228 spatial lag and spatial error. The spatial lag model (also known as contagion model) 229 incorporates space as a right hand-side variable, estimating a coefficient for the spatial 230 effect; the error model does not incorporate spatial as a covariate, but includes it in the 231 structure of the residuals (81). Conceptually, spatial lag models seem more appropriate to 232 adjust for spatial autocorrelation in the case of infections, since it is expected that the 233 number of COVID-19 cases in one municipality affects the cases in the neighboring 234 areas, the contagion effects. However, this is not necessarily true for mortality, 235 particularly once controlling for the case incidence rate. In this case, a spatial error model 236 appears more suitable, since unobserved spatial effects are expected to drive the spatial 237 autocorrelation in the residuals. Consequently, spatially correlated regressions of cases 238 are adjusted using a spatial lag model, and an error model is utilized for the death 239 regressions.
Incidence and mortality data were collected and calculated using Microsoft Excel.

Descriptive statistics and multivariable regressions were estimated using STATA, and 242 spatial analysis and visualizations were conducted in GeoDa. Table 2 shows the descriptive statistics of the sample. First, it is observed the large 246 heterogeneity in most variables between municipalities, both in the dependent and 247 independent variables. As stated before, this reflects the different realities within the MR, 248 as well as the differences in terms of COVID-19 outcomes. Second, spatial 249 autocorrelation appears as statistically significant for all the variables of interest 250 . To identify how different variables relate to COVID-19 infections and deaths, several 278 multivariable regressions were estimated. Table 3 presents the results for the infection-279 related dependent variables. As shown in Table 1 , each variable has three different ways 280 to be measured: cumulative incidence rate (columns 1 and 2), peak of cases (columns 3 281 and 4), and days to the peak (columns 5 and 6). Table 4 presents the same set of estimations for the mortality variables. In this case, four 307 different models are estimated for each one of the independent variables, cumulative 308 mortality rate (columns 1 to 4), peak of deaths (columns 5 to 8), and days to the peak of 309 deaths (columns 9 to 12). As before, each model is estimated using either the 310 multidimensional poverty index or a set of socioeconomic factors; additionally models 311 . The first result is that the determinants of infections and deaths are not the same.

However, as expected, some variables seem to explain variation in both types of explaining cumulative rates than peaks and days to the peak, and the overall fit (R 2 ) is 328 larger than for the infection regressions in Table 3 . As before, using Poisson regressions 329 for days to the peak does not change the main results.

Unlike the infection regressions, in this case, the hypothesis of a random spatial 331 distribution of the residuals is rejected in 8 out of 12 cases, highlighting the need to use 332 spatial regression models to take into account the presence of spatial autocorrelation.

Based on the results from Tables 3 and 4, a simplified set of regressions is estimated. A 334 potential problem with inference, in this case, is related to the degrees of freedom due to 335 a large number of explanatory variables and the relatively small sample (n=52). Table 5 336 shows these reduced models, based on the previous results (infection and deaths OLS First, adding a spatial dimension removes the spatial correlation in the residuals in six 357 cases where OLS residuals show spatial autocorrelation: days to peak of cases (column 358 1), peak of deaths (columns 2 to 5), and days to peaks of deaths (columns 6 to 10).

However, overall the results improve, reflecting the addition of a previously omitted 360 significant variable. Not only overall fit increases (R 2 ) but also results in terms of 361 . As Table 6 shows, the percentage of 362 children and the rurality reduces the magnitude in the peak of deaths but makes it quickly 363 (reduce the days to the peak). The opposite occurs for multidimensional poverty, again, a 364 risk factor to explain the level and velocity of deaths. The speeding effect is also 365 observed for the percentage of people 65+, migrants, overcrowding, and distance to 366 health centers, while the years of education increase the number of days to reach the 367 peak. As before, population density shows positive and significant coefficients for the 368 peak of deaths regressions. can be assumed in the short-term as "explanatory" but be used for long-term planning; on 400 the other hand, the second group of indicators are "policy tools" and can be used as 401 control knobs to short-term responses to the pandemic.
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review) preprint

body_text.text: The article has some limitations that need to be taken into account when interpreting the 403 results. First, there are time-differences between dependent and independent variables: 404 while dependent variables reflect information between March and July 2020, independent 405 variables come mainly from a survey carried out three years before. Unfortunately, there 406 is no other municipality-level representative source with more updated information. 407 However, most of the variables are expected to be similar today. There are at least two 408 reasons for this. First, aggregated data is expected to change slower than individual-level 409 data. Second, as discussed above, most variables reflect structural factors-such as 410 demographic and socioeconomic features-that are not expected to change significantly 411 . CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license It is made available under a is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. (which was not certified by peer review) preprint

The copyright holder for this this version posted September 18, 2020. . in a three-year period. This is also expected for "policy tools" variables (such as the 412 patterns of use of public transportation) in absence of a policy shock. Second, there is a 413 difficulty in choosing the concrete way to measure the relevant outcomes. Of course, 414 different specifications can lead to different results. In this analysis, the issue was 415 confronted by using several perspectives (infections and deaths, and levels and change).

The Metropolitan Region is a good case for spatial analysis but other geographical areas 423 could also be of interest to understand the COVID-19 dynamics and policy responses 424 (e.g. for establishing regional or international sanitary customs). FIGREF0.text: 160COVID-19 since the start of the pandemic (59-60). Second, we included poverty as an161    indicator that captures several risk factors associated both with higher rates of infection162 and death. Poverty is associated with people's vulnerability to COVID-19 and impacts 163 the variables of interest through several channels: poor sanitary conditions, access to 164 information, inability to follow prevention strategies-such as handwashing, the use of 165 facemasks, and social distancing-, and lower access to healthcare, among others. (61-166 65) The CASEN survey includes a variable called multidimensional poverty, an index of 167 socioeconomic vulnerability that summarizes several aspects related to social 168 determinants and COVID-19 (see Supplementary Material 2). Using this index has 169 advantages and disadvantages. On the one hand, it simplifies the estimation by capturing 170 several socioeconomic factors into one variable, as used in other studies (68, 69). On the 171 other hand, it hinders the understanding of the underlying channels through which social 172 determinants impact health outcomes. As highlighted by Victor Fuchs "If we constantly 173

FIGREF1.text: All dummy variables were transformed to capture the percentage of people reporting each 188 condition in each municipality. Continuous variables represent the municipality's average 189 value. The survey's expansion factor at municipal-level was used to expand the sample's 190 values to a population estimate. A detailed definition of each variable is presented in 191 Supplementary Material 3. 192 The selected variables cover an ample spectrum of dimensions (demographic, health, and 193 socioeconomic factors) related to the impact (infection and deaths) of COVID-19. In 194 terms of the spatial analysis, they include variables to explain geographical variations 195 based on compositional issues (i.e. differences in the kind of people who live in each 196 place) as well as contextual explanations (i.e. differences between the places), 197understanding that both are relevant in the relationship between health and place(79).

FIGREF3.text: As previously stated, one of the most salient features when performing municipality-level208 analysis in the Metropolitan Region in Chile is the presence of geographic clusters, 209 particularly when looking at socioeconomic indicators. Considering the way in which 210 COVID-19 is transmitted and the potential differences in access/quality of healthcare, we 211 expect space and place to play an important role in determining both, values in the 212 independent and dependent variables, as well as their interactions. This justifies the use 213 of spatial analysis in the study.

FIGREF5.text: 220 COVID-19 in the region, we use ordinary least squares (OLS) regressions. If space and 221 place are relevant in determining the variables in our analysis, then the errors in the OLS 222 regressions are spatially-correlated and, consequently, the results are biased (80). To test 223 the presence of spatial correlation on the OLS regression, the global Moran's I test-that 224 indicates both the existence and degree of spatial autocorrelation (82)-is applied to the 225 .

FIGREF6.text: gives a first warning on the potential effect of space between COVID-19 261 outcomes and municipal-level features. Spatial autocorrelation and measures can be 262 broadly classified into global and local measures (83). Moran's I is a global test that 263 indicates the presence of spatial correlation; a local test can be used to answer where this 264 correlation is. Fig 2 shows the results for the Gi* tests in selected dependent and 265 independent variables. The Gi* identify areas where the values of the variables are high 266 or low (hot and cold spots detection) respect to the global average (83). The figure 267 exhibits clusters around the Santiago downtown area vs peripheric municipalities, as well 268 as an east-west pattern, particularly for socioeconomic variables.

FIGREF8.text: is noted that the determinants of level and change in infections differ. As 289 expected, the use of public transportation shows a significant and positive association 290 with cumulative incidence rate; results for change-type regression (columns 5 and 6) are291 less consistent, with the share of people 65+, rurality, self-employment, green spaces, and 292 difficulty to get healthcare showing significant coefficients. Second, multidimensional 293 poverty appears as important to explain the number of cases (columns 1 and 3), while the 294 effect vanishes when looking at the impact of a set of socioeconomic variables instead of 295 the index of socioeconomic vulnerability (columns 2 and 4). The effect, as expected, is 296 also positive showing that multidimensional poverty is a risk factor for COVID-19 297 contagion at the municipality level. Third, the model's overall fit is better in the level-298 type regressions, explaining 60% of the variation in the dependent variables. In the case 299 of estimations 5 and 6, count models using Poisson regression were also estimated; 300 results-in terms of significance and sign of the coefficients-hold when using this 301 alternative. 302 Finally, Moran's I tests for spatial autocorrelation of the residuals show that the 303 hypothesis that OLS residuals are distributed randomly in the space cannot be rejected for 304 all models. Consequently, there is no statistical justification for adjusting to consider 305 spatial effects.306

As in the case of infections, level-type and change-type estimations present 320 common and specific determinants.321 For deaths, for level-type variables (columns 1 to 8) the share of people over 65 years 322 old, population density, multidimensional poverty, and the prevalence of cases have 323 significant and positive coefficients; overcrowding and distance to a health center also 324 contribute to explain whether a municipality reaches the peak of cases faster or slower. 325 Just like in the case of infection models, multidimensional poverty captures an effect that 326 is not explained by a broad set of socioeconomic factors. The model also does a better job 327

FIGREF12.text: 337 regressions). As emphasized above, both variables (cases and deaths) share some 338 explanatory variables and differ in others. In this case, it is also observed that level-type 339 and change-type models have different determinants. Notably, the overall fit of the model 340 using a reduced set of independent variables is similar to the one obtained in Tables 3 and 341 4, showing that an important proportion of the variation in the variables of interest can be 342 explained by a small set of variables.343

FIGREF13.text: municipality-level data on 52 administrative units, the article explored the effects 372 of different sets of variables, acknowledging the need to consider a broad set of variables, 373 as well as time dynamics and spatial effects in the analysis.

FIGREF14.text: Several conclusions are drawn from the results. First, there are common and idiosyncratic 375 elements that explain the prevalence and dynamics of infections and mortality. It is 376 necessary to recognize these different approaches when discussing the "impact" on 377 COVID-19. In this line, the proposed models are better explaining variation in levels of 378 infections and deaths than changes (measured as days to the peak). Research on the 379 outcomes of COVID-19 needs to incorporate different perspectives (measures of impact 380 and determinants) to shed light on the problem. Second, as long as different models are 381 required to tell different stories (34 estimations in this case), a significant part of the 382 municipal variation in infections and deaths can be explained by a rather small number of 383 variables (as in Table 5). In any case, all the results highlight the role of social 384 determinants of health in explaining the dissimilar impact of COVID-19 in the MR as 385 well as other findings in other countries about unequal distribution of COVID-19 (83-86).

FIGREF15.text: line, the use of multidimensional poverty index as a determinant of COVID-19 387 outcomes is an interesting result; the indicator shows to be relevant to explain infections 388 and deaths, doing a good job capturing the complex nature of the problem, highlighting 389 the role played by structural determinants-particularly with poverty and vulnerability-390 and showing similar outcomes to other studies (87-90)This result has more relevance 391 considering that COVID-19 also has an impact on socioeconomic factors, generating a 392 vicious circle between both problems (91-93). Third, the results identify different types of 393 variables that explain the COVID-19 outcomes: demographic, health-related, and 394 socioeconomic. However, these determinants can also be grouped according to their 395 degree of changeability. Some of the relevant indicators can be seen-at least in the short 396 run-as fixed (such as poverty and age distribution), while others are more likely to be 397 changed (like the use of public transportation and the availability of a health center). 398 From a public policy perspective, this classification is useful: the first group of indicators 399

FIGREF16.text: In a similar vein, methodological choices are also required when selecting the unit of417 analysis. In this case, we focused on municipalities and used percentages of individuals 418 (instead of, for example, households) to calculate the independent variables. Finally, 419 regarding spatial analysis, the definition of neighbors is also a crucial one; although in 420 this case the selection of contiguous units is justified by the features of the data (the 421 existence of units of different sizes and the spatial patterns of the variables of interest).

FIGREF17.text: presents a multi-perspective analysis of the COVID-19 impact in the 428 Metropolitan Region, Chile. It provides several interesting insights for understanding the 429 patterns and dynamics of the disease, and highlights the need to look at social 430 determinants of health and spatiotemporal dynamics in the analysis of COVID-19 (94). It 431 also opens a large space for further research questions that could not be answered here. 432 One important question related to the outcomes and relationships once the pandemic is 433 finished. The use of a 100-days period allows us to understand the evolution of the 434 disease so far but it is a snapshot of an ongoing issue. Additionally, better availability and 435 quality of data can help to understand the underlying factors behind the changes in outcomes. We proposed an imperfect indicator for measuring the speed of 437 changes. There are still relevant questions to answer in this line. Finally, the estimations 438 are based on municipalities' structural features; the understanding of COVID-19 439 outcomes can also improve by adding real-time variables related to people's behavior, 440 such as the percentage of people using face masks, or better data on mobility within and 441 between geographical areas. 442 We believe the analysis contributes to the worldwide effort for understanding the social 443 determinants and effects of the COVID-19. Our results can be used to promote health in 444 all policies and to enhance intersector efforts to face this pandemic. We expect these 445 results to be particularly useful for policymakers, and hope they can encourage the 446 implementation of evidence-based solutions and tailored interventions to help minimize 447 the negative effects of the pandemic tackling social inequalities.
